header.title: Labour MP admits 'We female MPs are sent death and rape threats'
header.subtitle: A SINGLE mother who won a stunning Parliamentary election has revealed she has suffered vile online abuse since becoming an MP. But defiant Rosie Duffield is urging more women to become MPs - telling them: Don't let the trolls put you off.
header.postText: 'Ms Duffield sent shockwaves through Westminster when she landed Canterbury for Labour in 2017, the first time the party had ever won in the constituency. She revealed she has since suffered abuse from trolls and has also experienced sexism from her male colleagues. But she insists she has no regrets about taking on the job and is now supporting 50:50 Parliament - the campaign for equal representation.', 'The former teaching assistant, who left school at 16, is determined to inspire women to sign up and bring a better gender balance to Government.', 'Ms Duffield, 47, said: Nowadays online abuse is probably something that does put people off.You are putting your head above the parapet.', 'You get death threats and rape threats and threats of physical violence. Men just get told they are not good enough. With women it's always violence. And it is quite scary sometimes.', 'But she added: We need more women in Parliament. The laws that we pass and the things that we debate without women pressuring men are there things that we would get aired?', 'Would we talk about domestic violence ? Would we talk about childbirth ? How likely is that ? ', 'It's not a deliberate conscious thing, there are some great men here, but unless we're here as well representing the things that we have to deal with daily then they are not going to get talked about or solved.', 'Her advice to other women ? Don't give up, don't give up! Get involved in whatever level of politics you feel comfortable in.', 'Ms Duffield's interest in politics began when she moved from London to Canterbury and then unexpectedly became a single mother at 27, going on to have another son.', 'Her boys are now aged 19 and 16.', 'Her experiences of raising her two children while living on benefits made her want to help other people like her. Meeting campaigner Frances Scott who set up the 50:50 campaign, inspired Ms Duffield to stand and led led to her unexpected becoming an MP.', 'Frances told me, 'We're always looking for women to stand ', 'Ms Duffield said. I went, I don 't think they have people like me. I don't think I 'm allowed to do that. I haven't got a degree.I 'm a single mum with two children. I haven't got any money and I'm a teaching assistant.', 'Frances said 'That's the kind of woman that we think should stand. ', 'After a recount she was elected by 187 votes in the 2017 general election. I was totally in shock, Ms Duffield recalled.'
